comments.commentBody: Here we are on Russia's border sending our senators and state department employees to stir up trouble in Ukraine and to have NATO shake its fist at Russia and we are crass enough to accuse Russia of aggressiveness, presumably as a cover up for our own going out of our way to make trouble thousands of miles from our own borders.  NATO is really the United States pentagon dressed in neutral colors and seemingly acting as a sales agent for our war machine industries.  On the other side of the world we are stirring up trouble in the Spratley Islands on the apparent theory that these tidal disappearing pieces of real estate are  priceless adjuncts to the United States interests even though thousands of miles from our shores.  Sounds as if a great deal of military and diplomatic hokey pokey is going on behind the scenes.

NATO is the American Imperial Military Force. It represents the "military-industrial complex". It is a financial burden on the American people. It has caused havoc and division in the middle east region with the resulting growth in terrorism which NATO now uses as a  reason for its continuing existence. Its ultimate purpose is the destruction of Russia. It is now on Russia`s borders preparing for the final invasion. It should be disbanded before it leads us into a world nuclear war.

Having shrunk Russian domestic spending, Putin may lack the resources to wage
war.

As long as the US pays for NATO (75% at last count), it will be difficult to argue that it's the Europeans who want and need NATO.

Downsize US funding to, say, 25% and let's see what happens then.

Putin is hoping to use control of the states surrounding the Russian Federation to force them to do enough business with it to sustain it's economy enough to support and sustain it as a modern state. The demographics have dictated that the existing Russian state is going to have too many old people for it's young people to afford to sustain them and the state as a whole, meaning that in a decade or two it will be a poor country in decline. In addition, while Russia can sell a lot of oil, it has nothing to offer the world in the way of exported goods besides arms, so it's economy is a boom/bust petro state, which simply cannot sustain a modern state as an international power. That leaves one path to a possible solution, power politics based upon war and the threat of war. It means that we need NATO, now, more than ever, to keep Russia from starting a third World War in Eurasia.

Obama called for the Arabs/Muslims to furnish the ground troops for this Isis war with little results. Mean while Isis begin atrocities that created millions of Arab/Muslims of refugees driving them from their homes and every one wrings their hands in grief... But here in the millions are the ground troops so sorely needed- a miracle !!! Trans port all able bodied ones to NATO military bases for arming and training to be returned to their homelands to become the new terrorists this time against the Isis militants. they can come in tanks and pickup trucks, with planes and drones over head, and blind rage in their hearts screaming for revenge ??? Meanwhile other refugees can sew uniforms, make war materials, grow foods stuffs, become the work force of support for their fighting men and future citizens and voters to perhaps desire form of government that may force peace in the middle east for the next 100 years. Allah be praised ??? HOW ABOUT IT OBAMA, HILLARY, BERNIE ???

From what I have learned, NATO is an anachronism, but beyond that, for some Americans and others, due to its involvement in bombing Serbia and attacking Libya and its military role in both Afghanistan and Iraq (and now Syria), the acronym NATO translates into North Atlantic Terrorist Organization!  It is counter-productive and in its bombing and destruction of Muslim countries only creates more radicalized terrorists. Violence begets even more violence.

It takes a lot of twisting for Russia to see NATO as an offensive threat. Imagine if you lived next door to a giant, someone who could easily kill you with a single slap of their hand. They claim to be friendly in one breath, then threaten you in the next. You live day to day wondering if the giant is going to smash your house to bits and build a new wing of his house on the remains. Then you notice that a bunch of your neighbors have banded together into a powerful group that says, "You can't intimidate us. We will rise to defend one another. Together, we are just as powerful as you." Who wouldn't want to join that group, rather than take their chances with the 'friendly' giant? If the giant would just leave his neighbors be, there wouldn't need to be any groups of neighbors at all. Everyone could just live in peace.

I would like to begin by saying that there is absolutely nothing that I agree with the megalomaniacal presumptive Republican candidate for President on, with the one exception of NATO being "obsolete".

With the fall of the Soviet Union it was. The only reason that it currently exists in its present form is the western countries (in particular the US) detain for the military restraints imposed by the the US adoption of the United Nations Charter in 1946. With what amounts to a "rubber stamp" backing by "NATO" members it allows the US to engage in all sorts militarily inspired international mischief without an authorization from the UN Security Counsel (such as in Yugoslavia, Iraq and Syria to name a few of the more predominant.

Bottom line, the very existence of NATO as a foil to the restrains imposed by the UN Charter requirements for the use of military force is the major reason that the modern world is in such political and religious turmoil.

The trouble with NATO is the EU's ambivalence. The article states that the countries which are deploying troops to Poland and the Baltic States are Canada, Germany, Britain and the United States. Only Germany is a long term EU member. Germany is a  half-hearted participant at best and will do the bare minimum. Most EU countries are not serious about defense. They don't spend enough and polls in most European countries show that surrender is the preferred option if the Russians attack the Baltic States. Nato has a problem and it has nothing to do with Brexit.

Instead of the subservient nodding to the Russophobia permeating everything the US political and military establishment does and says these days, which brings up the '50s, where kids were taught to look for Reds under the table, the Times could have done a great public service by presenting a different take on NATO and its relevance.
Isn't one of the basic tenets of the so-called 'Western value system' the free press and with that, the right to dissent?
Or, how about inviting Mr. Putin to pen another op-ed piece, as he did in 2011 to present his side?
Isn't the rimary responsibility of a newspaper to make people think?
NATO is doomed to failure until they invite Russia to join.

To be frank, I find NATO useless.Why is it that the Europeans cannot protect themselves? They have every capacity to do so. We-the US- invest billions of dollars while Americans starve under bridges, our educations system crumbles and our infrastructure resembles a Banana Republic

We are not the world's policeman. It is hypocritical of D.C. to go spend/protect other countries, other people while they swore to protect us and meet the needs of the American people here at home first.

Europe should claim a majority of all the responsibility on their continent. Not howl everytime they have an issue for US rescue. We have our own problems to attend. And if they wish to maintain NATO, they should put up the money/resources. NATO is more for their benefit than ours.

The editorial fails to point out the U.S. role in Russia's increased belligerence. As former Defense Secretary William Perry's new book points out, it was unwise to expand NATO in 1996 when relations with Russia were at their high point. he along with fifty other U.S. leaders, including Sam Nunn, Bill Bradley, Paul Nitze, signed a letter to Pres. Clinton opposing the expansion. Clinton went ahead anyway, urged on by Richard Holbrooke. From there things went down hill for U.S.-Russian relations, predictably so. Russia took the expansion as a threat.

Question: has it ever been a possibility that Russia be admitted to NATO, while all other eastern European nations have that possibility? I assert not, which is all the reason you need to understand the tensions.

replies.commentBody:
AQ wasn't a factor when the USSR collapsed in 1989. Likewise, by that time the USSR had withdrawn from Afghanistan so the mujahadeen weren't that important to us.

The job of NATO wasn't just to integrate Germany but also to keep the Soviet Union (which had engineering a coup in Czechoslovakia and done the Berlin blockade and was moving full steam ahead to bring eastern Europe under its boot). Letting them in NATO would've been pointless.

comments.commentBody:
You talked about soul searching. Right?

After the cold war, both Clinton & Bush treated Russia like what France and Belgium treated the Weimar Republic. It was a perfect situation to join hands against enemies like AQ & (later ISIS). But, we joined hands with AQ light (Al Nusra) to fight a Russian puppet, like the cold wars days (Mujahedin of the yesteryears)

The job of the NATO was initially to prevent future war in Europe by keeping the Germans integrated (or down). Russia also wanted to join NATO in 1953 but Churchill preferred the cold war to start to support the British philosophy of 'balance of power'.

Today ask yourself, who apart from USA & Turkey, is serious about NATO in terms of $$ investment. Ask the hard questions. Germans are no longer 'down'.

NYT is just "liberal in name"
They completely lost standard and fairness view
just being biased democrat zealot
NATO does't need to exist since Soviet Union was gone
Russia's aggression??
NATO broke the promise and expand to just the front yard
of russia Okay If US faces the unfriendly army near Cuba or somewhere
How would you act?

We pay 75% of Matos expenses – many members spend next to nothing but believe that Article 5 guarantees that the US will come to their rescue. Some nations the US has bullied into joining but for others they join for Article 4 which they believe guarantee US military support while they spend their money on social programs. US Generals look at NATO as way to keep the US military in Europe.

As the years roll on NATO members get weaker and weaker and more dependable on the US taxpayer. Only the French and the UK have armies that make some contribution to the NATO forces. The rest of the countries are nothing but takers whose defense is whatever the US taxpayer will provide.

Under these financial conditions the US should stop funding NATO in Europe and tell the Europeans that there will be no Article 5 protection unless they pay their bill. Also we need to stop bring in weak states like Georgia and Ukraine which has no business in NATO and we are wrong to even think of including them thus increasing the US Taxpayer burden.

Are you even aware of the weakened or non-existent state of the armies of some of these countries. They couldn't defeat the NYC POlice force

We pay 75% of Matos expenses – many members spend next to nothing but believe that Article 5 guarantees that the US will come to their rescue. Some nations the US has bullied into joining but for others they join for Article 4 which they believe guarantee US military support while they spend their money on social programs. US Generals look at NATO as way to keep the US military in Europe.

As the years roll on NATO members get weaker and weaker and more dependable on the US taxpayer. Only the French and the UK have armies that make some contribution to the NATO forces. The rest of the countries are nothing but takers whose defense is whatever the US taxpayer will provide.

Under these financial conditions the US should stop funding NATO in Europe and tell the Europeans that there will be no Article 5 protection unless they pay their bill. Also we need to stop bring in weak states like Georgia and Ukraine which has no business in NATO and we are wrong to even think of including them thus increasing the US Taxpayer burden.

The real threat is the Pacific and China. Stop wasting money on NATO and Europe which is weak, helpless mess.

replies.commentBody:
"Excellent opinion by the NYT Editorial Board. "
Sure thing, as long as it says what you want to hear.
That's not free press; it is subservience.

comments.commentBody:
Excellent opinion by the NYT Editorial Board.

The problem with Russia is that its leaders are afraid. Its top guy, and the select power group around him, is afraid of the West, of its free press, democracy, and justice. Afraid that the same thing could happen there as it has to other similar regimes such as those of Saddam Hussein and Muammar al-Gaddafi. If they were to step down and the Russian people would finally be able to take back their freedoms and democracy, they would no doubt face justice. So to stay in power, the regime lies to and cheats the Russian people, and provokes and threatens the west. The theats are made out of weakness and fear, like a wounded and scared animal. It shows clearly that Russia is not strong, it is weak. But it is still very dangerous for European and world peace, not least due to its nuclear arsenal and its large army and navy at Europe's borders, which clearly threaten especially the Baltic states, combined with the total unpredictability of the current leadership which seems to need conflicts to justify their positions.

NATO's response is therefore appropriate, because the only message that's understood is military strength.

Russia's leadership should, and probably do, understand that NATO is a defensive organisation only, comprising a large number of countries none of which would ever want a war against Russia, so NATO in itself poses no threat to Russia and would never threaten it, as long as Russia itself stays peaceful.
How much money does the NYT get from the MIC?

replies.commentBody:
1. deterrent, not 'deterrant'
2. "Mr. Putin has repeatedly signaled his intentions to increase Russia's sphere of influence, not only in Europe, but in other continents as well."
Care to tell, where exactly?
3. If you think that the US can just bomb Russia a little here and there, without being hit, you're more naive, than you sound.

@waldo
1. Thank you for noticing the typo. But it seems you noticed little else.
2. You have heard of Syria, haven't you?...Well, it' not in Europe (and neither is Antarctica).
3. I NEVER said, nor do I think that the U.S. should "just bomb Russia a little here and there"...or anywhere else.
Please try to get the story straight.
Another thing.
I lived in Berlin when it was divided and surrounded, and traveled around other East Bloc countries when they were still under Soviet authority.
I know what I'm talking about.

comments.commentBody:
For anyone who spent any amount of time behind the "Iron Curtain" during the height of the Cold War, the Russian presence in Europe was a very grim reality -- It's no surprise that those countries that have expressed concern about another incursion have done so.
History does have a way of repeating itself.
And Mr. Putin has repeatedly signaled his intentions to increase Russia's sphere of influence, not only in Europe, but in other continents as well.
Being a member of NATO doesn't doesn't necessarily mean that the U.S. will be forced into any kind of a protracted conflict with Russia, but its ability to serve at least, as a deterrant, is undeniable.

The editorial board's assessment of the friction between NATO and Russia is as Orwellized as it is predictable, and many serious journalists have noted same

https://consortiumnews.com/2016/07/11/nato-reaffirms-its-bogus-russia-na...

Whether or not NATO has outlived its purpose, one should remember the involvement of NATO in bombing Serbia to free Kosovo [now run by an Albanian mafia, more or less] when considering Crimea - particularly as this seems to be, with the Syrian proxy war [in which the US has armed Al Qaeda linked groups, without any doubt].

As to Crimea/Ukraine:

https://consortiumnews.com/2015/03/22/crimeans-keep-saying-no-to-ukraine/

The US wanted to park its navy in Crimea. Russia could never allow that.

I'm sure "The Grand Chessboard" has been translated into Russian.

July 15, 2016

The art for geopolitical strategy is best appreciated in the NATO classic power alliance projecting interest. What was once called carrying a big stick and for specifics when challenged by the ever trident opponents testing seeking opportunistic and ‘savage,’ destabilizing misguided threats to stability…

Jja Manhattan, N. Y.

NATO is just another in a long list of failed 20th century institutions that the out-of-touch elites in positions of authority keep telling each other is relevant, when in fact it has been irrelevant, and just "going through the motions", for more than a decade.

The fact that the headline talks about "Keeping NATO Relevant" is a measure of just how out-of-touch the Editorial Board is with the 21st century world that we live in, and it is growing by the day.

The irony is that NATO has now actually become crucially important, which makes its current irrelevance an indictment of the leadership of all of its members.

So who's going to pay for it? Not us, anymore, I hope. Time for France and Germany to step up.

A few things need to be considered:

If Brexit it carried-out to finality, Britain might become more and more isolated from the rest of Europe. New P.M. Theresa May has appointed "Leave" advocates to key Cabinet posts, And abrasive Boris Johnson as Foreign Secretary! Many EU members have not been enthusiastically in favor of economic sanctions--against Russia--since they hurt their own foreign trade.

As UK's divorce from EU progresses, that could encourage other nations to follow suit. And, the Exit of a EuroZone member nation could even be more horrific.

So far, Europe has merely been addressing the various symptoms, at the national level. If an ultimate solution is ever to be attempted, the members need to address it at the corpus--at Brussels--at the European Union itself.

Basically, by reaching for too much authority, the EU appears to be coming an authoritarian government, rather than a trade pact, which promotes peace on the Continent--and cooperation in solving common problems.

https://thetruthoncommonsense.com
